page.title: Pre/Post-Positional Phrases - Other Complements
page.introduction: In addition, some prepositions or postpositions can stand alone without a complement, such as in the sentences Come [right in] and John turned the light [on/off]. Also, consider whether your language allows prepositions or postpositions to be stranded with questions, as in Who(m) did you give the book [to _ ]?

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language allow any prepositions postpositions prepositions and postpositions to stand alone as in any of the English examples above?

form.prompt: Key some examples of stand alone prepositions postpositions prepositions and postpositions from your language included in simple full sentences here:
form.instruction: Since your language has only clitic prepositions, postpositions, prepositions and postpositions, it should not be possible for them to stand alone. If you do have forms which can stand alone, go back and change the earlier answer to "some of each type".
form.introduction: Most languages will allow locative adverbs as complements of prepositions or postpositions, such as over there and in here.

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language allow locative adverbs as complements of prepositions? postpositions? prepositions and postpositions?

form.prompt: Key some examples with locative adverbs as complements here:
form.instruction: Since your language has only clitic prepositions, postpositions, prepositions and postpositions, we will assume that they can attach to adverbs, but the phrasal category in this situation wll remain AdvP, not change to PP.
form.introduction: Locative prepositions and postpositions are a special group in that they can take another locative PP as their complement. English examples of this type include: up [to the top], around [behind the shed] and over [by the table].

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have any locative prepositions postpositions prepositions and postpositions which take a locative PP complement?

form.prompt: Key some examples of locative PP complements of locative prepositions postpositions prepositions and postpositions here:
form.instruction: The rule allowing the PP complements is restricted to only locative stand alone prepositions or postpositions. Therefore, in the lexicon, you need to add the feature locative to all the prepositions postpositions prepositions and postpositions which can take a locative PP complement.

Since your language has only clitic prepositions, postpositions, prepositions and postpositions, if two locative prepositions postpositions prepositions or postpositions attach, it will still come out as a single locative PP (or locative AdvP if the head is an adverb).
form.introduction: Some prepositions or postpositions can also have sentences or participle phrases as their complements, as in before [the rain stops], before [signing the contract], while [John was at the store], after [John came home], and after [buying our new house].

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have any prepositions postpositions prepositions and postpositions which take a sentential complement?

form.prompt: Key some examples of sentential complements within PPs, included in simple full sentences here:
form.instruction: No rules currently allow sentential complements for languages which have only clitic prepositions postpositions prepositions and postpositions which attach to the head (normally a noun). If your language has such sentential complements, please send data in full sentences with interlinear glosses to Cheri_Black@sil.org so the correct rules can be added.

Since the only PP examples that come to mind with sentential complements have temporal prepositions, postpositions, prepositions and postpositions, the grammar rule allowing sentential complements is currently restricted in this manner. Therefore, in the lexicon, you need to add the feature temporal to all the prepositions postpositions prepositions and postpositions which are temporal and/or can take a sentential complement.
